articles.description:
KATHMANDU, Nepal, Nov 15 (IPS) - The UN Secretary General’s Policy Brief on Meaningful Youth Engagement in Policy and Decision-making Processes offers several ideas on how to ensure youths have a bigger and more relevant role within the UN System.

Read the full story, “A Bigger and More Relevant Role for Youth Within the UN System - Part II”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: A Bigger and More Relevant Role for Youth Within the UN System - Part II

articles.description:
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov 15 (IPS) - US President Joe Biden’s Indo-Pacific Framework for Prosperity (IPEF) is the economic arm of his administration’s Indo-Pacific Strategy, aimed at countering China’s influence in the region.

Read the full story, “IPEF: New Cold War Weapon Backfires”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: IPEF: New Cold War Weapon Backfires

articles.description:
NAIROBI, Nov 15 (IPS) - It is a terrifying life experience, cut off from the world and trapped in forced labour aboard fishing vessels, often in high seas or seas beyond the territorial waters of any state. The fishers are isolated under hazardous and horrific working conditions under limited regulatory oversight. More than 128,000 fishers were trapped in forced labour aboard fishing vessels in 2021 alone.

Read the full story, “Forced Labor: Exposing Dark Web of Fisheries Labour Abuses”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Forced Labor: Exposing Dark Web of Fisheries Labour Abuses

articles.description:
The Security Council has passed a resolution calling for the immediate release of all hostages held by Hamas and for urgent and extended humanitarian corridors throughout the enclave to save and protect civilian lives. The affirmative vote came following four unsuccessful efforts to take action last month.

Read the full story, “Israel-Palestine crisis: Security Council calls for urgent, extended humanitarian pauses in Gaza”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Israel-Palestine crisis: Security Council calls for urgent, extended humanitarian pauses in Gaza

articles.description:
The UN migration agency IOM on Wednesday appealed for safe migration pathways in the wake of a recent shipwreck off the coast of Yemen.

Read the full story, “World News in Brief: Dozens dead in Yemen shipwreck, Pakistan expulsions ‘must stop’, FAO aids Sudan farmers”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: World News in Brief: Dozens dead in Yemen shipwreck, Pakistan expulsions ‘must stop’, FAO aids Sudan farmers

articles.description:
Grave violations against children, including killing, maiming and abductions, are taking place in the Gaza Strip, according to the Executive Director on the UN Children’s Fund, UNICEF.

Read the full story, “First Person: UNICEF chief in Gaza visit, bears witness to grave violations against children”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: First Person: UNICEF chief in Gaza visit, bears witness to grave violations against children

articles.description:
Greenhouse gas emissions reached a record high in 2022 with “no end in sight to the rising trend”, the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) said in a report published on Wednesday.

Read the full story, “‘No end in sight’ to rising greenhouse gas emissions, UN weather agency warns”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: ‘No end in sight’ to rising greenhouse gas emissions, UN weather agency warns

articles.description:
The UN’s top emergency relief official unveiled a 10-point plan “to rein in the carnage” in Gaza on Wednesday which focuses on a major expansion of aid into into the wartorn enclave, along with a new call for humanitarian ceasefires and the release of hostages taken during Hamas’s 7 October terror attacks on Israel.

Read the full story, “Israel-Palestine crisis: UN emergency relief chief unveils 10-point plan ‘to rein in the carnage’”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Israel-Palestine crisis: UN emergency relief chief unveils 10-point plan ‘to rein in the carnage’

articles.description:
Children have been killed, maimed, abducted and denied assistance in Gaza, and the parties to the conflict must “stop this horror”, UN Children’s Fund ( UNICEF ) chief Catherine Russell said during a visit to the enclave as humanitarian operations there ground to a halt on Wednesday for lack of fuel.

Read the full story, “Gaza: ‘Hospitals are not battlegrounds’, children’s suffering must stop, UN humanitarians say”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Gaza: ‘Hospitals are not battlegrounds’, children’s suffering must stop, UN humanitarians say

articles.description:
PORTLAND, USA, Nov 14 (IPS) - Tragically, the numbers of deaths of men, women and children in Israel and the Gaza Strip have surged to unprecedented levels following the Hamas attack on Israel on 7 October 2023.

Read the full story, “Deaths in the Israel-Hamas Conflict”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Deaths in the Israel-Hamas Conflict

articles.description:
NAIROBI, Nov 14 (IPS) - Smallholder farmers from the Global South benefit from a grossly disproportionate 0.3% of international climate finance despite producing a third of the world's food and despite holding the key to climate-proofing food systems.

Read the full story, “Smallholder Farmers Gain Least from International Climate Funding”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Smallholder Farmers Gain Least from International Climate Funding

articles.description:
KATHMANDU, Nepal, Nov 14 (IPS) - The recent appointment of Dr. Felipe Paullier of Uruguay as the first Assistant Secretary-General for Youth Affairs is a good news for the United Nations. Yet we need to ask ourselves the following question: Can such development also become a real hope, rather than just a symbolic change, for millions of youths from around the world?

Read the full story, “A New Youth Envoy: Symbolic Change or Real Hope?-- Part I”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: A New Youth Envoy: Symbolic Change or Real Hope?-- Part I

articles.description:
HYDERABAD, INDIA, Nov 14 (IPS) - 'If you ask what climate justice is, then the litmus test for climate justice is at the local level. So, climate justice needs to be judged by how many people are protected from climate-vulnerable conditions that they have no hand in creating.' – Gernot Laganda, Director of Climate Change Adaptation and Disaster Risk Reduction at the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP)  It is crucial to narrow the gaps and ensure that climate finance goes to where people are most vulnerable, says Gernot Laganda, Director of Climate Change Adaptation and Disaster Risk Reduction at the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP)—especially as the most fragile states only receive USD 2.1 per capita while non-fragile states receive USD 161.

Read the full story, “Time to Convert Climate Change Rhetoric into Action, Says WFP's Gernot Laganda”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Time to Convert Climate Change Rhetoric into Action, Says WFP's Gernot Laganda

articles.description:
The United States need to increase efforts to address “enduring systemic racism” at what is a critical juncture in the fight against discrimination, said the UN Human Rights Council-appointed expert on the issue, following her first official visit to the country.

Read the full story, “US ‘at a critical juncture’ in fight against racism: Independent expert”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: US ‘at a critical juncture’ in fight against racism: Independent expert

articles.description:
The top UN humanitarian official in Ukraine has condemned deadly Russian shelling in the southern city of Kherson on Monday.

Read the full story, “Ukraine: UN official ‘utterly outraged’ by brutal attack in Kherson”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Ukraine: UN official ‘utterly outraged’ by brutal attack in Kherson

articles.description:
Police officers serving under the UN flag must be properly prepared, equipped and resourced in the face of the significant challenges to both multilateralism and peacekeeping, the Security Council heard on Tuesday.

Read the full story, “Security Council: UN Police need greater support amid ‘many challenges’”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Security Council: UN Police need greater support amid ‘many challenges’

articles.description:
The COP28 climate conference held in Dubai later this month “must be the place to urgently close the climate ambition gap”, as emissions continue to rise and climate chaos intensifies, UN chief António Guterres insisted on Tuesday.

Read the full story, “‘Close the climate ambition gap’ says UN chief ahead of COP28”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: ‘Close the climate ambition gap’ says UN chief ahead of COP28

articles.description:
One hundred years after the discovery of insulin, millions of people with diabetes around the world still cannot access the care they need, risking severe complications, WHO warned on Tuesday’s World Diabetes Day.

Read the full story, “World News in Brief: Diabetes on the rise, UN prisoners in Yemen, Ukraine war fuels rise in landmine casualties”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: World News in Brief: Diabetes on the rise, UN prisoners in Yemen, Ukraine war fuels rise in landmine casualties

articles.description:
Cholera vaccines are expected to arrive in Sudan this month as the country continues to face a deadly outbreak of the disease amidst the ongoing war, the UN humanitarian affairs office, OCHA, said on Tuesday.

Read the full story, “Humanitarians step up response to deadly cholera outbreak in Sudan”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Humanitarians step up response to deadly cholera outbreak in Sudan

articles.description:
KIGALI, Nov 13 (IPS) - In a newly established Centre of Excellence located in Masaka, a suburb of the Rwandan capital city, Kigali, an expanded lab, complete with innovative facilities and specialized instruments, is now giving surgeons a conducive environment to simulate how to perform minimally invasive surgeries.

Read the full story, “New Robotic-Assisted Surgery Offers Inspiring Hope for Rwanda”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: New Robotic-Assisted Surgery Offers Inspiring Hope for Rwanda

articles.description:
NEW YORK, Nov 13 (IPS) - Unless Israel establishes an exit strategy and an end-game that will lead to a solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict in full coordination with the US and Saudi Arabia, the war against Hamas will only be another brutal violent episode that will prepare the ground for the next conflagration that will engulf the West Bank and potentially set the entire region on fire.

Read the full story, “What Is Israel's End-Game in Gaza?”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: What Is Israel's End-Game in Gaza?

articles.description:
UNITED NATIONS, Nov 13 (IPS) - One month into the war in Gaza, Palestine has already seen major setbacks in development that will have severe ramifications for the people of Palestine that will impact any future efforts toward its economic recovery.

Read the full story, “‘Taking Palestine Back to 2005’ — UN Warns of Socioeconomic Impacts of Gaza War”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: ‘Taking Palestine Back to 2005’ — UN Warns of Socioeconomic Impacts of Gaza War

Want Cash Out of Your Home? Here Are Your Best Options

sources.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

articles.description: Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan criticized Israel, calling it a "terror state" that commits war crimes and violates international law in Gaza. He accused Israel of conducting a military campaign with unlimited support from the West and called for Israeli leaders to be tried for war crimes. Erdogan also reiterated that Hamas is a political party and not a terrorist organization. He will be visiting Germany to meet Chancellor Olaf Scholz and called on Germany to support a ceasefire in Gaza. Turkey has been sending humanitarian aid and medical support to Gaza, including bringing cancer patients to Turkey for treatment.
articles.title: Turkey's Erdogan labels Israel a 'terror state', slams its backers in West

articles.description: North Korea has criticized the recent visit of top US defense officials to South Korea and has vowed to respond with more "offensive" actions to what it perceives as military threats from the United States and its allies. The North Korean defense ministry blamed the United States for raising tensions in the region. The visit by US Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin resulted in a revised bilateral security agreement between South Korea and the US to address North Korea's nuclear and missile threats.
articles.title: North Korea vows more offensive response to US 'threats'

articles.description: The UN Security Council has approved a resolution calling for humanitarian pauses and corridors throughout the Gaza Strip, but the resolution does not mention a ceasefire. The watered-down resolution also does not refer to Hamas' surprise attack on Israel or Israel's retaliatory airstrikes. The resolution asks all parties to comply with their obligations under international law, particularly in protecting civilians. The Security Council has been paralyzed by internal divisions between China and Russia, who want an immediate ceasefire and the United States which objects.
articles.title: UNSC adopts resolution on humanitarian pauses in Gaza

articles.description: JERUSALEM: A woman abducted by Hamas militants on October 7 has given birth in captivity, the wife of Israel's PM has said in a letter to US First Lad.
articles.title: Hostage gave birth in Gaza captivity: PM's wife to Jill Biden

articles.description: Middle East News: SAN FRANCISCO: The US did not give Israel any kind of green light for its raid on Gaza's main hospital, the White House said Wednesday, adding that su.
articles.title: White House: US did not give OK for storming hospital

articles.description: Qatari mediators were on Wednesday seeking to negotiate a deal between Hamas and Israel that includes the release of around 50 civilian hostages from Gaza in exchange for a three-day ceasefire, an official briefed on the negotiations said. It would mark the biggest release in hostages held by Hamas since the militant group burst through the Gaza border, attacked parts of Israel and took hostages into the enclave. ​​Hamas has agreed to the general outlines of the deal, but Israel has not and it is still negotiating the details, the official said.
articles.title: Qatar seeking deal to free 50 hostages: Report

articles.description: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has announced plans to pass an emergency law in response to a ruling by the UK's top judges that his scheme to send asylum seekers to Rwanda was unlawful. Sunak stated that he is working on a new treaty with Rwanda to designate it as a safe destination for migrants. He also warned that Britain could potentially leave the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) in order to proceed with deportation flights. The Rwanda scheme is a key element of Sunak's immigration policy ahead of next year's elections.
articles.title: UK can't deport migrants to Rwanda: SC

articles.description: US & Canada News News: Amal Reji from Ettumanoor in Kerala's Kottayam district was arrested for allegedly shooting and wounding his 32-year-old pregnant wife, Meera Abraham,.
articles.title: Kerala man held in US for shooting at pregnant wife

articles.description: In a historic move, New York State Governor Kathy Hochul has signed legislation making Diwali a holiday for public schools in the city. The legislation requires that all public schools be closed on the "15th day of the eighth month of the Indian calendar in each year, which is known as Diwali," a press release said.  Kathy Hochul said the legislation is "an opportunity for our children to learn about and celebrate traditions from across the world."
articles.title: Diwali declared a holiday in NYC public schools

articles.description: A bipartisan group of US Senators has demanded documents from Meta Platforms CEO Mark Zuckerberg regarding the company's research on the harm caused to children by its social media platforms. The senators claim that Meta has been unresponsive and provided misleading information in previous requests for information. The demand follows the recent testimony of a whistleblower and the unsealing of a complaint filed by the Massachusetts Attorney General, both of which suggest that Meta executives were aware of the harm caused by their products.
articles.title: Senators demand documents from Meta on social media harm to children

articles.description: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak plans to pass an emergency law and potentially quit the European human rights convention after the UK Supreme Court ruled that his scheme to send asylum seekers to Rwanda was unlawful. Sunak intends to work on a new treaty with Rwanda to declare it a safe destination for migrants. He also signaled the possibility of leaving the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) to allow deportation flights to start next year.
articles.title: UK PM Sunak vows emergency law after top court rules Rwanda migrant scheme unlawful

articles.description: Chinese companies are purchasing US chipmaking equipment to produce advanced semiconductors, despite efforts to curb China's advancements in the US semiconductor industry. A report by the US-China Economic and Security Review Commission criticizes the export restrictions implemented by the Biden administration, stating that importers can claim the equipment is being used on older production lines to bypass restrictions. China has stockpiled equipment by taking advantage of time gaps between the implementation of regulations in different countries.
articles.title: China received US equipment for advanced chips despite restrictions: Report

articles.description: Uganda's President Yoweri Museveni on Wednesday denounced the United States and UK for issuing adverse security advisories to their citizens in Uganda, and accused both countries of creating and conserving insecurity in Africa. Last week the US and UK both issued travel warnings urging their citizens not to travel to Jinja town in eastern Uganda to attend a cultural festival that was held over the weekend, with the UK citing the killing of tourists and the risk of threats against foreigners.
articles.title: Uganda's president Museveni criticises US, UK for security advisories

articles.description: Pakistan and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) have reached an agreement for the release of a $700 million second tranche of a $3 billion bailout package. This agreement comes as a major relief for Pakistan, which has been facing a severe balance of payments crisis. The IMF team has praised Pakistan's stabilisation policies and highlighted the need for continued efforts to build resilience in the face of external risks. The successful conclusion of talks is expected to help stabilize Pakistan's economy as it approaches general elections
articles.title: IMF reaches staff-level agreement with Pakistan on $700 million bailout review

articles.description: UK News: LONDON: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said on Wednesday his government will introduce emergency legislation that will confirm that Rwanda is a sa.
articles.title: UK's Sunak says emergency law will ensure legal action can't delay Rwanda migrant flights

articles.description: Lebanon's military tribunal has released a man accused of killing an Irish UN peacekeeper on bail, while four others remain at large. The accused, Mohamad Ayyad, was charged with the killing of Pvt. Sean Rooney in December 2022. Ayyad was released due to "deteriorating health," according to reports. Unifil is monitoring clashes between Hezbollah militants and Israeli troops along the border. The Irish military and Unifil are urging that all perpetrators be held accountable for the killing.
articles.title: Lebanon releases man suspected of killing Irish UN peacekeeper on bail

articles.description: Hunter Biden has requested subpoenas for documents from Donald Trump and former Justice Department officials, alleging that Trump applied political pressure to a criminal investigation against him. Biden's attorneys claim that there were instances suggesting improper and partisan pressure by Trump on the investigation. The request for subpoenas comes as defense attorneys fight a federal firearms case against Hunter Biden, who is accused of breaking laws against drug users having guns.
articles.title: Hunter Biden calls for a Trump subpoena, saying political pressure was put on his criminal case

articles.description: The European Union has proposed a new package of sanctions targeting Russia and its associates, aiming to tighten measures since the invasion of Ukraine and add more economic operators. The proposal will now be discussed among the 27 member states in order to reach a unanimous decision. Talks have focused on imposing export restrictions on Russia's diamond industry. The proposal comes after a visit by Nato Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg to the EU Commission.
articles.title: EU moves closer to imposing a new set of sanctions on Russia for its war on Ukraine

articles.description: KHYBER PAKHTUNKHWA: The Pakistan Security Forces killed seven terrorists during an intelligence-based operation (IBO) in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa's Tank dis.
articles.title: Pakistan: Security forces kill seven terrorists in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa

articles.description: Estonian prime minister Kaja Kallas has expressed her interest in becoming the next secretary general of Nato. Kallas, who has been a vocal supporter of Ukraine and a critic of Russia, made her statement during the Politico Defense Summit in Washington. Nato's current chief, Jens Stoltenberg, is set to step down in 2024. However, some Nato diplomats and experts have raised concerns about Kallas being too hawkish for the alliance. Kallas's popularity in Estonia has also been affected by revelations about her husband's business activities in Russia.
articles.title: Estonia's prime minister Kaja Kallas signals her interest in Nato's top job

articles.description: The US House of Representatives has passed a temporary spending bill to avoid a government shutdown. The bill, which would extend government funding until mid-January, now awaits approval from the Senate. The legislation has received support from both Democratic and Republican leaders. The bill would provide more time for lawmakers to work on detailed spending bills. Some Republicans have expressed frustration that the bill does not include spending cuts and border-security measures.
articles.title: US House passes spending bill to avert government shutdown

articles.description: ​Russian President Vladimir Putin has approved changes to the law that governs presidential elections putting new restrictions on media coverage, local news agencies reported on Tuesday.The changes come ahead of the election to be held in March in which Putin, who has ruled Russia for the last 24 years, is expected to seek a new six-year term. ​Putin, 71, has not declared whether he will run, saying he will announce that only after the parliament formally sets the election date.
articles.title: Putin approves new restrictions on media coverage ahead of Russia's presidential elections

articles.description: More than 400 political appointees and staff members representing some 40 government agencies sent a letter to President Biden on Tuesday protesting his support of Israel in its war in Gaza. The letter calls on the president to seek an immediate ceasefire in the Gaza Strip and to push Israel to allow humanitarian aid into the territory. It is the latest of several protest letters from officials throughout the Biden administration
articles.title: More than 400 US officials protest president's Israel policy

articles.description: Israel has released a video claiming that Hamas is using hospitals as cover in Gaza, showing weapons and explosives allegedly found in a children's hospital. The video has been disputed by Gaza's health ministry, which acknowledged that it was filmed inside the hospital but disagreed with the Israeli claims. The video contained assertions that could not be verified, such as a piece of paper that Israeli officials claimed was a schedule for guarding hostages. The health ministry said it was a regular work shift timetable.
articles.title: Israeli video brings Gaza hospital to centre of information war

articles.description: During President Joe Biden's meeting with President Xi Jinping, China's diplomats are concerned about what Xi will see from his window and want to ensure there are no protesters. Expectations for substantive agreements are minimal, with only a resumption of military-to-military communications and discussions about keeping AI software out of nuclear command and control systems likely to be announced. There is no plan for a joint statement, and both governments will provide their own account of the discussions.
articles.title: US, China may resume military-to-military talks after Biden-Xi meet

articles.description: ​Terry Gou, the billionaire founder of major Apple supplier Foxconn, has collected three times the amount of signatures needed to qualify to run in Taiwan's presidential elections. Gou thanked his backers for their "enthusiastic support" and vowed to work hard to achieve "peace across the Taiwan Strait".Gou, who stepped down as Foxconn chief in 2019, had to gather around 300,000 voter signatures by November 2 to qualify as an independent candidate. The election commission said he got more than 900,000 valid signatures.
articles.title: Foxconn founder qualifies to run for Taiwan president

articles.description: ​US President Joe Biden's 2024 reelection team on Monday said Donald Trump had embraced the language of Nazi German dictator Adolf Hitler by using the word "vermin" to refer to his political enemies.Trump told a rally in New Hampshire on Saturday he would "root out the communists, Marxists, fascists and the radical left thugs that live like vermin within the confines of our country that lie and steal and cheat on elections," repeating his false claim that fraud cost him the 2020 presidential election.
articles.title: Biden campaign says Trump use of 'vermin' echoes Hitler

articles.description: During a recent spacewalk, two NASA astronauts accidentally lost a tool bag while performing routine maintenance outside the International Space Station. The bag is currently floating in space, about 250 miles above Earth, and is expected to remain there for a few months before disintegrating. Although the tools in the bag were not needed for the entire spacewalk, it is unclear what specific tools were lost. This is not the first time a tool bag has been lost during a spacewalk, as a similar incident occurred in 2008.
articles.title: 2 Nasa astronauts lost a tool bag in space. Earthlings may even be able to see it

articles.description: A Russian delegation, led by natural resources minister Alexander Kozlov, is visiting Pyongyang, North Korea. The visit comes as North Korea announces progress in its banned ballistic missile program. The talks between Russia and North Korea are focused on economy, science, and technology. The Russian delegation aims to develop substantial cooperation with North Korea based on agreements made by Russian President Vladimir Putin and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. Additionally, North Korea reported successful static tests of new-type high-thrust solid-fuel engines for intermediate-range ballistic missiles.
articles.title: Russian resources minister visits North Korea amid new missile development

articles.description: US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping will meet before the APEC summit in San Francisco to address the tense rivalry between their countries. The summit aims to prevent conflict and will cover global issues such as the Middle East conflict, Russia's invasion of Ukraine, Taiwan, human rights, and fair trade. The US hopes for progress in reestablishing military ties and combating the trade in fentanyl. However, experts do not expect any breakthroughs or substantial changes in the relationship.
articles.title: What to expect when Biden meets Xi Jinping in San Francisco

articles.description: A federal judge has rejected attempts by major social media companies to dismiss nationwide litigation accusing them of illegally enticing and addicting children to their platforms, causing mental health damage. The decision covers hundreds of lawsuits filed on behalf of individual children who allegedly suffered negative health effects from social media use. The ruling stated that the companies could be sued for negligence over their duty to design safe products and warn users of defects, but they were not obligated to protect users from harm caused by third-party users.
articles.title: Social media companies must face youth addiction lawsuits, US judge rules

articles.description: Three people were killed and 15 others injured when a charter bus carrying students from a high school was rear-ended by a semi-truck on an Ohio highway. The crash involved five vehicles, including the charter bus that was transporting students to a school conference. The cause of the accident is still unknown. Emergency responders were at the scene, and injured individuals were being treated at seven hospitals. This is the second fatal crash involving high school students on a charter bus in recent months.
articles.title: 3 dead, 15 hospitalized when bus carrying students and truck crash on Ohio highway, officials say

articles.author: Srinivas Laxman
articles.description: A report by the Federation of American Scientists (FAS) suggests that the trend of countries sharing nuclear weapons is increasing and will continue to do so in the future. While there are nine countries that own the majority of nuclear warheads, there are several others that participate in nuclear mission-related activities. The report highlights that nuclear sharing refers to non-nuclear countries operating launchers to employ another state's nuclear weapons during war.
articles.title: Nuclear sharing trend gathering momentum, says FSA report

articles.description: A top Ukrainian military official said Russian troops continued simultaneous assault attempts in several directions on the country's east, now launching even more attack drones. Kyiv's counteroffensive aimed at retaking occupied land in the country's south and east has not managed to move as fast as expected due to heavy mining and strong defensive lines of Russian troops. In mid-October, Russian soldiers launched a massive offensive campaign near the eastern town of Avdiivka, followed by an intensification in other frontline sections in the east.
articles.title: Ukraine says Russia tries to push on east, involves more drones

articles.description: Iraq's top court said on Tuesday it was dismissing parliament speaker Mohamed al-Halbussi, an influential Sunni Muslim politician, after a lawmaker's complaint over the alleged "falsification" of a document. Halbussi has been the highest ranking Sunni official since he first became speaker in 2018 of parliament -- elected with the support of Iraq's powerful pro-Iran parties. He was reelected as speaker in January 2022 following early parliamentary elections the previous October.
articles.title: Iraq Supreme Court says dismissed powerful parliament speaker

articles.description: Israel's foreign minister, Eli Cohen, criticized United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, stating that he has not condemned Hamas enough and is too close to Iran. Cohen made these comments during a press conference at the UN building in Geneva. He also called for Guterres to speak out against Hamas and free Gaza from their control. Cohen met with the World Health Organization and International Committee of the Red Cross, expressing his expectation for them to gain access to Israeli hostages held by Hamas.
articles.title: Israel's foreign minister Eli Cohen says UN chief not fit to lead

articles.description: President Joe Biden has stated that the United States is not seeking to distance itself from China, but rather wants to improve the relationship. The two leaders will meet at the APEC summit in California, with Biden hoping for a return to normal correspondence and military contact between the two countries. However, Biden also expressed wariness about investing in China. While progress has been made on trade, issues such as Taiwan and military expansion remain red lines for China.
articles.title: Ahead of Xi Jinping talks, Joe Biden says US 'not trying to decouple from China'

articles.description: Assam chief minister Himanta Biswa Sarma praised Prime Minister Narendra Modi, calling him not only the leader of India but also the most popular leader in the world. Sarma stated that wherever Modi goes, he is honored and respected, even in countries like the United States. He attributed this popularity to Modi's ability to deliver on his promises, which has gained people's confidence. Chhattisgarh is currently in the midst of elections, with the second phase scheduled for November 17.
articles.title: People consider PM Narendra Modi as world's most popular leader: Himanta Biswa Sarma

articles.description: A woman found murdered 31 years ago in a river in Belgium has been identified over three decades later thanks to her flower tattoo and an international appeal, Interpol said on Tuesday. The Lyon-based global police organisation said she was Rita Roberts from Cardiff in Wales and British. Roberts, found lying against a grate in the river Het Groot Schijn in Antwerp on June 3, 1992, had a tattoo of a black flower with green leaves and the inscription "R'Nick" on her right forearm.
articles.title: 'Flower tattoo' British woman identified 31 years after murder

articles.description: India has requested evidence from the US authorities under the Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty (MLAT) in connection with an attack on the Indian consulate in San Francisco in July this year, sources informed. New Delhi has sent a request amid an ongoing probe into the incident by the National Investigation Agency (NIA). A total of 45 people were identified in connection with the attack through crowd-sourcing, the sources added. Notably, MLAT is an agreement between two or more countries for the purpose of gathering and exchanging information and evidence in criminal matters.
articles.title: India urges US for evidence in attack on San Francisco consulate: Sources

articles.description: A 1962 Ferrari 250 GTO sports car sold for $51.7 million in New York on Monday, making it the second most expensive car ever sold at auction, Sotheby's said. The 250 GTO went on sale Monday evening after a few minutes of bidding in the auction room, but at a price lower than the more than $60 million expected by RM Sotheby's, the luxury car subsidiary of the auction house.
articles.title: 1962 Ferrari auctioned for $51.7 million in New York

articles.description: Satellite imagery reveals that a plant in Russia is being constructed to mass produce Iranian-designed kamikaze drones, which are expected to be used against Ukrainian energy facilities. The construction progress is evident in the satellite images, but no sanctions have been imposed on the plant's owner or associated companies. The report suggests that Russia may accelerate its attacks on Ukraine's energy infrastructure, leading to harsh living conditions. The Ukrainian President has also warned of potential strikes on energy infrastructure.
articles.title: Construction progresses at Russian plant for Iranian drones - report

articles.description: The Maldives Speaker of parliament Mohamed Nasheed resigned on Monday, days before the swearing-in of a new president following a fiercely contested election in the Indian Ocean archipelago. Parliamentary elections are not due until the second quarter of next year, meaning that president-elect Mohamed Muizzu - who takes power on Friday - will have to work with an opposition-controlled parliament. "He didn't want a no-trust vote against him and decided to resign," the aide said.
articles.title: Nasheed quits as Speaker ahead of presidential inauguration

articles.description: Suella Braverman, a hard-right politician, has been fired twice from the position of home secretary due to her divisive rhetoric and actions. She was first dismissed for a security breach involving the sending of a government document to an unauthorized lawmaker. Braverman has faced criticism for her stance on law enforcement, immigration, and national security, including her description of asylum seekers as an "invasion" and her inaccurate narratives about criminal gangs.
articles.title: Braverman is no stranger to controversies

articles.description: British PM Rishi Sunak has appointed David Cameron, the former prime minister who campaigned to remain in the EU, in a move to signal that the Conservatives are not lurching to the right. The decision to bring back Cameron and fire interior minister Suella Braverman, a prominent supporter of leaving the EU, has been seen as a risky strategy. Sunak has been trying to keep all wings of the party happy and portray himself as a tough decision-maker. However, the party still lags behind Labour in the polls.
articles.title: Cameron return aims to help win over moderates

articles.description: The government of El Salvador has implemented a $1,130 fee on travelers from African countries and India who connect through the nation's main airport. While the fee is described as an "airport improvement fee," it comes amid US pressure to control migration flows to its southern border. The measure is believed to be aimed at reducing migration, particularly to Nicaragua, a transit point for migrants from Haiti, Cuba, and Africa trying to reach the US. The move could potentially benefit El Salvador President Nayib Bukele's reelection campaign, despite criticism of his human rights record.
articles.title: Curbing migration to US? El Salvador slaps a fee on African & Indian travellers

articles.description: Some 900 earthquakes hit southern Iceland on Monday, authorities said, adding to tens of thousands of tremors that rattled the region in recent weeks as the country braces for what could become a significant volcanic eruption. Almost 4,000 people were evacuated over the weekend as authorities feared that molten rock would rise to the surface of the earth and potentially hit a coastal town and a geothermal power station. "We have this tremendous uncertainty now; will there be an eruption and if so, what sort of damage will occur," said Matthew James Roberts,
articles.title: 900 tremors hit town in Iceland, scores shifted

articles.author: NAOMI CANTON
articles.description: Five Afghan Hindus from the same family, including three children, have died in a massive house fire in Hounslow that ripped through their mid-terraced home on Diwali when a huge number of fireworks were set off, reports Naomi Canton. Police were called at 10.30pm Sunday to reports of a fire in Channel Close. Ten fire engines and 70 firefighters attended the scene. It took them three hours to get the blaze under control. The bodies of five people, including three children, were found on the first floor and pronounced dead at the scene.
articles.title: 5 Afghans from a family die in UK housefire on Diwali

articles.description: US and international forces in northeastern Syria were attacked with drones and rockets at least four times in the past 24 hours, though there were no casualties , a US military official said on Monday. US forces came under attack three times on Sunday evening, including near the Al Omar Oil field and at a US base at al-Shaddadi, the official said. Multiple drones were fired at US forces at the Rumalyn Landing Zone on Monday, the official said.
articles.title: 'US forces in Syria attacked 4 times in less than 24 hours'

articles.description: Israeli tanks have positioned themselves outside Gaza City's main hospital, Al Shifa, as part of their effort to gain control of the northern half of the Gaza Strip. Medics inside the hospital report that patients, including newborns, are dying due to a lack of fuel. The hospital is currently under siege, with Israeli snipers and drones firing into the building. Israel claims that the hospital is being used by Hamas fighters as a shield, which Hamas denies.
articles.title: Israeli tanks outside Gaza hospital; patients, babies, medics stranded

articles.description: A search-and-rescue group in British Columbia recommends using a paper map and compass instead of relying on street map programs. This advice comes after two hikers had to be rescued because they followed a non-existent trail on Google Maps. The group, North Shore Rescue, deployed a helicopter and rope rescue team to help a stranded hiker in a steep area with cliffs. In a separate incident, Secret Service agents protecting President Joe Biden's granddaughter opened fire on three people attempting to break into an unmarked vehicle in Washington, D.C. No one was injured.
articles.title: Hikers get lost in Canada after taking a nonexistent trail on Google Maps

articles.description: A video of US President Joe Biden at a wreath-laying ceremony has gone viral, with many claiming that he appeared disoriented and confused. During the ceremony, Biden hesitated and seemed unsure of his surroundings after placing the wreath. He sought guidance from a service member who directed him back to the lineup. This incident is not the first time Biden has attracted attention for his actions, as he previously fell on stage during a graduation ceremony in June.
articles.title: Joe Biden 'confused' at wreath-laying ceremony in Arlington

articles.description: Violence in Burkina Faso has resulted in over 70 deaths, including children, this month. The country has been dealing with a jihadist insurgency since 2015, leading to the deaths of thousands and the displacement of millions. A recent attack in the town of Zaongo resulted in numerous deaths, mostly elderly people and children. The European Union and the US government have condemned the violence, and authorities are conducting investigations to determine responsibility. The transitional government in Burkina Faso has urged caution in drawing conclusions.
articles.title: Over 70 killed including children in Burkina violence this month: Prosecutor

articles.description: A British convert to Islam, Aine Leslie Davis, has been sentenced to eight years in prison in the UK after pleading guilty to terrorism charges. Davis, who was convicted in Turkey for being part of the Islamic State group, had been deported from Turkey after serving a seven-and-a-half-year sentence. Prosecutors stated that Davis had a firearm for terrorism purposes and had funded terrorism. Davis had been suspected of being part of the IS cell known as "The Beatles" that tortured and killed Western hostages in Syria.
articles.title: A British man is sentenced to 8 years in prison over terror offenses with the Islamic State group

articles.description: Around 40 Spanish citizens were evacuated from Gaza through the Rafah border crossing into Egypt. They are part of a larger group of Spaniards and their family members, totaling between 140 and 170 people, who requested evacuation. Spain has received authorization from Israel for a second group of around 80 people to leave Gaza. The crossing between Gaza and Egypt opened on November 1st, allowing foreign passport holders and wounded Gazans to leave.
articles.title: Around 40 Spanish citizens have left Gaza, foreign minister says

articles.author: Omer Farooq Khan
articles.description: Pakistan's claims of neutrality in the Russia-Ukraine conflict have been questioned after revelations of ammunition sales worth $364 million to private US companies supplying arms to Kyiv. The contracts, signed in August 2022, involved two companies, Global Military and Northrop Grumman. While no concrete evidence has surfaced, Pakistan has not ruled out the possibility of the weapons reaching Ukraine through the black market. Pakistan's overall arms exports increased significantly to $415 million in 2022-23 from $13 million in 2021-22.
articles.title: Ammunition sales test Pakistan's 'neutral' claim on Ukraine war

articles.description: The United States is working hard to achieve a strong consensus leaders' statement at this week's Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit. The wars in the Middle East and Ukraine have made it difficult to draft a summit declaration, but the US is aiming to replicate the success of last year's summit in Thailand, where a consensus leaders' declaration was announced. Russia will be represented by officials not subject to US sanctions as president Vladimir Putin will not be attending.
articles.title: US says it's working hard to have a strong consensus leaders' declaration at Apec

articles.description: A US judge has granted a request to investigate a website that is providing false and misleading information about a $5.6 billion settlement between retailers and Visa and Mastercard over card fees. The judge has set a deadline for the website to respond to the inquiry. The website closely resembles the official court-authorized page for the settlement, and fraud claims have arisen from similar cases in the past.
articles.title: US judge orders probe of phony Visa, Mastercard settlement website

articles.description: Maryanne Trump Barry, former President Donald Trump's older sister and a former federal judge, has died at 86, media reports said on Monday, citing sources. The New York City Police Department said an 86-year old female was found unconscious and unresponsive inside the bedroom of a Fifth Avenue apartment and was later confirmed dead. An investigation was ongoing and her identity could not be released, the department said. Trump Barry died at her home in Manhattan and was found early Monday morning, the report said.
articles.title: Donald Trump's older sister Maryanne Trump Barry dies at 86: Media

articles.description: Ksenia Fadeyeva, an associate of imprisoned Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, has been jailed in the Siberian city of Tomsk pending trial on extremism charges. Fadeyeva, who used to run Navalny's office in Tomsk, has been charged with running an extremist group and promoting activities that infringe on people's rights. This is part of an ongoing crackdown. Navalny himself was convicted earlier this year on extremism charges and sentenced to 19 years in prison.
articles.title: Russia jails an associate of imprisoned Kremlin foe Navalny as crackdown on dissent continues

articles.author: Miriam Berger, Sarah Dadouch, Hannah Allam, Hajar Harb
articles.description: Palestinians called the storming of the hospital a “crime against humanity.” The Israeli military has accused Hamas of using Shifa and other hospitals to shield its operations.
articles.title: Israeli forces sweep into Gaza’s al-Shifa Hospital, packed with wounded

articles.author: Miriam Berger, Kelsey Ables, Victoria Bisset, Niha Masih, Andrew Jeong, Adela Suliman, Leo Sands, Dan Rosenzweig-Ziff, Sammy Westfall
articles.description: Israel and the United States have asserted that Hamas is operating out of al-Shifa, while doctors and aid workers have denied that militants are using them for cover.
articles.title: Israel-Gaza war live updates: Israeli forces release videos, photos from al-Shifa Hospital after ‘targeted operation’

articles.author: Louisa Loveluck, Meg Kelly
articles.description: For weeks, Israel has been building the case that al-Shifa hospital was the “beating heart” of Hamas’s operations in northern Gaza. Early Wednesday, troops moved in.
articles.title: How Israel built its case to raid Gaza’s al-Shifa Hospital

articles.author: Kelly Kasulis Cho, Sammy Westfall
articles.description: Israel says it started a “targeted operation against Hamas” at al-Shifa Hospital, Gaza’s largest medical center, which is housing patients and thousands of displaced people.
articles.title: What to know about Gaza’s al-Shifa Hospital

articles.author: Elahe Izadi, Timo Schober, Bastian Obermayer, Frederik Obermaier, Kate Brady
articles.description: German writer Hubert Seipel accepted support of Putin ally Alexei Mordashov, according to Cyprus Confidential documents, but says he maintained independence.
articles.title: Russian oligarch secretly funded journalist’s Putin book, documents show

articles.author: Joanna Slater
articles.description: About 240 hostages are being held in Gaza, according to Israeli officials. At least nine Americans and one legal permanent resident are believed to be among them.
articles.title: How the U.S. is trying to bring home American hostages held in Gaza

articles.author: Karla Adam
articles.description: The policy, considered extreme by human rights advocates, has been closely watched by other countries seeking to outsource migration.
articles.title: U.K. top court rejects plan to deport migrants to Rwanda, in blow to Sunak

articles.author: Amanda Coletta
articles.description: The Oscar-winning singer-songwriter Buffy Sainte-Marie taught the Count to count in Cree on “Sesame Street.” A Canadian Broadcasting Corp. investigation has cast doubt on her Indigenous ancestry.
articles.title: Canada’s most prominent Indigenous icon might not be Indigenous

articles.author: Miriam Berger, Hajar Harb
articles.description: Gaza’s humanitarian crisis is especially acute for women and girls, who lack access to sanitation and health care. Thousands of pregnant women fear giving birth.
articles.title: The heavy burdens of war for Gaza’s women and girls

articles.author: María Paúl
articles.description: The pūteketeke won in a heated electoral race that saw a global billboard campaign, accusations of fraud and a record number of votes.
articles.title: John Oliver interfered in an election — for ‘Bird of the Year’

articles.author: Christian Shepherd
articles.description: Chinese leader Xi Jinping is in San Francisco for a meeting with President Biden, with both sides looking to calm tensions. Climate change is a potential area of cooperation.
articles.title: In a breakthrough, U.S. and China agree to restart climate talks

articles.author: Rachel Pannett
articles.description: Rita Roberts’s body was found in an Antwerp river in 1992. The British woman was identified in an Interpol operation to solve cold cases across Western Europe.
articles.title: ‘Woman with the flower tattoo’ identified decades after her death in Belgium

articles.author: Ishaan Tharoor
articles.description: There’s a lot riding on the rare meeting between President Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping on Wednesday.
articles.title: Xi and Biden meet amid a fracturing world order

articles.author: Kelly Kasulis Cho, Rachel Pannett, Leo Sands, Adela Suliman, Bryan Pietsch, Sarah Dadouch, Maham Javaid
articles.description: President Biden, speaking at a news conference Monday, said that Gaza’s hospitals “must be protected” and that he is in contact with Israel about their safety.
articles.title: Israeli forces enter hospital in heart of Gaza City, IDF says

articles.author: Sarah Dadouch, Hazem Balousha, Miriam Berger, Maham Javaid
articles.description: As Israeli ground troops have advanced in northern Gaza, hospitals have been caught in the crossfire, with Shifa emerging as a focal point.
articles.title: Israeli forces enter al-Shifa Hospital amid collapse of Gaza’s medical system

articles.author: Ellie Silverman, Kyle Swenson, Jasmine Hilton, Joe Heim
articles.description: Thousands of demonstrators from across the country joined a pro-Israel rally in Washington that comes amid a deepening war in Gaza.
articles.title: At March for Israel in D.C., demonstrators demand Hamas release hostages

articles.author: Katharine Houreld
articles.description: The Ethiopian government will draw up the lists of the needy “jointly” with aid groups and community members.
articles.title: U.S. resumes assistance to Ethiopia after intense negotiations over corruption in aid program

articles.author: David   Stern
articles.description: Oleksandr Dubinsky, who helped Rudy Giuliani in his failed effort to dig up dirt on Joe Biden and Hunter Biden, was jailed on accusations of aiding Russia.
articles.title: Ukrainian lawmaker with ties to Giuliani arrested on treason charges

articles.author: Evan Halper, Dalton Bennett, Jonathan O'Connell
articles.description: After multiple changes of ownership, the fuel is sold to a Greek refinery that serves the U.S. military, a Post examination finds.
articles.title: Forbidden Russian oil flows into Pentagon supply chain

articles.author: Rachel Pannett, Niha Masih, Jennifer Hassan, Leo Sands, Sarah Dadouch, Sammy Westfall, Miriam Berger
articles.description: The World Health Organization says al-Shifa Hospital is no longer operational after days without water or power and fierce fighting in the area.
articles.title: Israel-Gaza war: Gaza’s two biggest hospitals in crisis amid fighting, bombardment, officials say

articles.author: Michael Birnbaum, John Hudson

articles.title: Blinken confronts State Dept. dissent over Biden’s Gaza policy

articles.description: Thousands are expected to rally to show solidarity with Israel, express resolve in combating antisemitism and demand the release of the hostages.

articles.description: With Israel asserting Hamas uses hospitals and other civilian structures to mask forces, humanitarian infrastructure is in the crosshairs of the ground assault.
articles.title: Civilian buildings increasingly at center of Israeli operation in Gaza

articles.author: Missy Ryan
articles.description: U.S.-based aid, advocacy and religious organizations warn that the provision of 155mm artillery rounds to Israel risks worsening civilian suffering in Gaza.
articles.title: Pentagon urged to halt plans for giving Israel artillery supplies

articles.author: Karla Adam
articles.description: In forcing the Brexit referendum, Cameron enshrined splits within the Conservative Party and provoked people to define themselves as Leavers or Remainers.
articles.title: David Cameron, who divided the U.K. with Brexit, is back in the cabinet

articles.author: Matthew Cappucci
articles.description: Magma is estimated to be less than a half mile below the surface, and rising.
articles.title: Iceland officials warn of ‘significant’ chance of volcanic eruption

articles.author: Louisa Loveluck, Susannah George, Sufian Taha
articles.description: The Israeli army, focused on Gaza, is relying increasingly on air power in the West Bank, though the strategy risks reenergizing Palestinian militants.
articles.title: Israeli drone strikes in Jenin signal new strategy, risk militant blowback

articles.author: Ruby Mellen, Artur Galocha, Júlia Ledur
articles.description: More than 11,100 Palestinians have been killed in Gaza since Oct. 7, according to Gaza’s Health Ministry. They include doctors, journalists, professors and poets.
articles.title: Gaza reports more than 11,100 killed. That’s one out of every 200 people.

articles.author: Drew Harwell
articles.description: U.S.-based platforms Facebook and Instagram show a remarkably similar gap, undercutting Republican arguments that China is influencing what appears on TikTok.
articles.title: TikTok was slammed for its pro-Palestinian hashtags. But it’s not alone.

articles.description: After a very encouraging consumer price index reading on Tuesday, we have more evidence that inflation’s truly cooling. But don't expect rate cuts soon.
articles.title: CNBC Daily Open: Despite cool inflation, don’t expect rate cuts

articles.description: U.S. President Joe Biden and President Xi Jinping of China are expected to discuss fentanyl flows, use of artificial intelligence and access to high-end tech.
articles.title: Earth is 'big enough' for U.S. and China to succeed, Xi says as he meets Biden

articles.description: Solana jumped on Wednesday amid an ongoing rally in altcoins and bullish remarks on the token from famed tech investor Cathie Wood.
articles.title: Solana surges amid altcoin rally, nearly triples its price over the past month

articles.description: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella told CNBC's Jon Fortt that the company has notable Chinese customers that operate outside the mainland
articles.title: Microsoft is fine avoiding China as U.S. considers national security implications, CEO Satya Nadella says

articles.description: Cruise, General Motors' embattled driverless car unit, said Tuesday it will pause all public road operations: supervised, manual and driverless.
articles.title: Cruise is taking all its vehicles off public roads amid expanded safety probe, staff changes

articles.description: Microsoft will give its Azure cloud clients more choices for standard computing workloads and artificial intelligence, following market leader Amazon.
articles.title: Microsoft announces custom AI chip that could compete with Nvidia

articles.description: Markets may be at least a tad optimistic, particularly considering the cautious approach central bank officials have taken.
articles.title: The market thinks the Fed is going to start cutting rates aggressively. Investors could be in for a letdown

articles.description: Red Bull has won 19 of the 20 Grand Prix weekends so far this season, led by world champion driver Max Verstappen.
articles.title: Red Bull's F1 dominance is translating to higher energy drink sales, team's principal says

articles.description: The U.S. Department of Defense has been investing billions of dollars in lasers over the last decade. Will these new weapons change the battlefield?
articles.title: Why the Pentagon is spending billions to bring laser weapons to the battlefield

articles.description: Donald Trump and his co-defendants asked a judge to grant a mistrial in the $250 million fraud case that threatens the former president's business empire.
articles.title: Trump requests mistrial in $250 million New York business fraud case

articles.description: Microsoft is giving its Copilot new capabilities while keeping the $30 monthly price the same. One Visa executive was already content with the assistant.
articles.title: Microsoft Office will now use AI to make meetings less painful
Wholesale prices fell 0.5% in October for biggest monthly drop since April 2020

articles.description: Under pressure to improve Citigroup's performance, the bank will announce layoffs starting Wednesday, CNBC has learned.
articles.title: Citigroup begins layoffs as part of CEO Jane Fraser’s corporate overhaul

articles.description: ValueAct began buying Disney this summer during the Hollywood strikes and it is now one of the investor's largest positions, the Activist Spotlight has learned.
articles.title: Activist investor ValueAct has been building a stake in Disney

articles.description: UBS Group CEO Sergio Ermotti says the "incredible" market demand for the bank's recent issuance of AT1 bonds is a "signal to the Swiss banking system."
articles.title: UBS boss Ermotti says 'incredible' bond demand is 'a signal to the Swiss banking system'

articles.description: Sega Chief Operating Officer Shuji Utsumi said that the company is thinking of bringing more of its lucrative intellectual property to other platforms.
articles.title: Sonic the Hedgehog helped revive 63-year-old Sega. The firm wants a repeat with its other classics

articles.description: China on Wednesday reported better-than-expected retail sales and industrial data for October, while the real estate drag worsened.
articles.title: China retail sales, industrial data grow faster than expected in October

articles.description: Siemens Energy has secured 7.5 billion euros in project-related state guarantees from the German government to safeguard the company's order book.
articles.title: Siemens Energy clinches state guarantees as it posts a 4.6 billion euro annual loss

articles.description: U.K. inflation fell sharply in October to a two-year low of 4.6% from 6.7% the previous month.
articles.title: UK inflation falls by more than expected in October to 4.6%, lowest in two years

articles.description: Kristalina Georgieva of the IMF said that the public sector should keep preparing to deploy CBDCs and related payment platforms in the future.
articles.title: IMF says central bank digital currencies can replace cash: 'This is not the time to turn back'

articles.description: German housebuilding is on the brink of collapse as construction is slowing, and the country's broader economy could be negatively impacted, experts say.
articles.title: German housebuilding is collapsing — and could drag the economy down with it

articles.title: 'Survival feels uncertain': Palestinians in Gaza describe desperation under Israeli bombardment

articles.title: China's unfinished property projects are 20 times the size of Country Garden

articles.description: Over 1,400 CEOs have stepped down from their positions between January to September, marking an almost 50% rise from a year ago.
articles.title: Is the Great Resignation over? Why bosses are leaving at record rates

articles.description: Japan's economy shrank in the July-September period for the first time in four quarters, provisional government data showed Wednesday.
articles.title: Japan's economy shrinks far more than expected in third quarter

articles.title: X, formerly Twitter, being 'overrun by trolls and lunatics' after Musk takeover, Wikipedia founder says

articles.title: CNBC Daily Open: Rational exuberance

articles.title: Here's why the UAW's record deals with GM, Ford and Stellantis aren't getting full support

articles.title: Alphabet pays Apple 36% of Safari search revenue, Sundar Pichai confirms

articles.title: PGA Tour says it will offer players equity ownership after it seals deal with investors

articles.title: GOP Sen. Mullin challenges Teamsters boss to fight at Senate hearing: 'Stand your butt up'

articles.title: Airbnb acquires AI startup for just under $200 million

articles.title: 10-year Treasury yield tumbles below 4.5% on cool October inflation report

articles.title: As Hollywood reckons with AI, Warner Music will use the tech to make an Edith Piaf biopic

articles.title: UBS sees a raft of Fed rate cuts next year on the back of a U.S. recession

articles.description:
Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images
    

  
Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated.
 Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. 
The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish government’s earthquake response. Much of that is focused on the emergency response — waiting for aid and rescue teams — but it is also extending to anger about policies before the earthquake, about how shoddy building construction may have exacerbated the devastation of the dis…
articles.title: Who is responsible for Turkey’s bad buildings?

articles.description:
Getty Images
    

  
How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy — and how we can do the same with some of our own.
 Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons.
That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia’s nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. “Nearly every commercia…
articles.title: 10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.

articles.description:
Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images
    

  
What Turkey and Syria’s deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth.
 In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. “It was like the apocalypse,” Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters.  
The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last week’s earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an u…
articles.title: Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live

articles.description:
A suspected Chinese spy balloon flies above Charlotte, North Carolina, on February 4, 2023.  | Peter Zay/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
    

  
As all these objects fall, a new space race is rising.
 Now that the US military has shot down a suspected spy balloon from China and three other unidentified flying objects, there will be debates about the UFOs’ meaning, their capabilities, and why they were all up there in the first place. 
Though former CIA Director Michael Hayden said the initial balloon’s threat to the welfare of Americans was vastly inflated, others described the incident as a wake-up call. Former Trump national security adviser H.R. McMaster hopes it will lead to a “Sputnik moment,” harkening back to the US space race with the Soviet Union. The Wall Street Journal even war…
articles.title: Why the balloon and UFO affairs are a Sputnik moment

articles.description: Images of protesters brandishing black and white banners during marches across Europe in support of the Palestinian people have been circulating online. Some accounts were quick to point out that these same flags have been brandished by al Qaeda, the Taliban and the Islamic State group. It turns out that this is a religious symbol that has been appropriated by terrorist groups. At the rallies, however, it was largely members of a radical group called Hizb ut-Tahrir that carried this banner.
articles.title: Are Islamist flags being waved in pro-Palestine protests? Not exactly

articles.description: Mali's army has recaptured the strategic northern town of Kidal, a stronghold of Tuareg-dominated separatist groups that has long posed a major sovereignty issue for the ruling junta. The capture is a significant symbolic success for Mali's military leaders, who seized power in 2020. France 24's Wassim Nasr takes a look at how the army were able to take back the city, including with the help of Wagner troops.
articles.title: Mali: How junta and Wagner forces seized control of rebel stronghold Kidal

articles.author: Quentin DUVAL
articles.description: People in Mexico’s southernmost state, Chiapas, have for the last year and a half, been living through a conflict between rival criminal groups. The Sinaloa Cartel and the Jalisco Nueva Generacion Cartel are both vying for control of the territory. The state, which borders Guatemala, has long been a hotspot for trafficking drugs, arms and migrants. But ravaged by years of inter-community conflicts, the security situation in Mexico’s poorest state is now spiralling out of control. In the face of growing insecurity, the left-wing rebel movement – the Zapatistas – recently announced that their self-managed municipalities, called “caracoles”, will be dissolved, in what looks to be a political retreat. Quentin Duval, Laurence Cuvillier and Ed Augustin report.
articles.title: Cartel turf war rages in Mexico's Chiapas as groups fight over territory

articles.description: After over a month of the Israel-Hamas war, journalists have had little, if any, access to the Gaza Strip. articles.description: A Vueling flight between Paris and Cairo made an emergency landing in Rome on Tuesday, November 7 where an Egyptian passenger was removed from the flight. Videos obtained by FRANCE 24 show the man being arrested by Italian police. The flight crew accused him of writing “I love Allah” on a form. It was a “blood-chilling scene,” says our Observer, who witnessed the whole incident and believes the man was racially profiled.
articles.title: Airplane makes emergency landing after Egyptian passenger writes 'I love Allah' on a form
